newsitem.title: INDIA: India Congress says ready for talks with rulers.
newsitem.headline: India Congress says ready for talks with rulers.

text.p: India's Congress party, which withdrew make-or-break support to the ruling minority coalition this week, said on Friday it was open for talks with Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's United Front alliance.

Congress spokesman Vithal Gadgil told Reuters that the party was strongly behind Congress president Sitaram Kesri but ready for talks to end a political crisis if the United Front made the first move. "Let the proposal come," he said.
Asked if Congress was open for talks to end the political crisis, Gadgil said: "Yes, yes."

Congress withdrew its support to the 10-month-old government on Sunday, citing what it said was the government's inability to tackle economic drift and combat communalism, a reference to Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

Analysts say the Congress, which has staked a claim to form a fresh coalition with support from the United Front or some of its constituents, has faltered in its bid for power ahead of a vote of confidence in Deve Gowda set for April 11.

The BJP and its allies control 193 votes in the 542-member lower house. The United Front has 180 votes and Congress 140. Deve Gowda would need a simple majority of members present and voting to win the confidence motion.
